Award.AwardTitle: Deformation, Damage, and Fracture of Light Metals and Alloys Symposium; TMS 2012, 141st Annual Meeting March 11-15,2012 in Orlando, FL
Award.AbstractNarration: This proposal requests funding in partial support of the Symposium on Deformation, Damage, and Fracture of Light Metals and Alloys, which is to be held at the TMS 2012, 141st Annual Meeting March 11-15, 2012 in Orlando, FL. This annual conference is organized by The Minerals Metals & Materials Society (TMS), to bring the Metals and Materials community together to present, learn about, and discuss recent developments in the field. This symposium will focus on deformation, damage, and fracture of light metals and alloys at room and elevated temperatures in their service environments. NSF funding will be used for registration-fee waivers for 6 students and 5 selected speakers or attendees, and partial support of the symposium proceedings. Qualified students, postdoctoral fellows, and select speakers or attendees will be identified by the organizing committee. In addition to student, postdoctoral researchers, and other authors that have already submitted abstracts for the symposium, the organizing committee may invite such candidates by contacting university departments and/or laboratories that are known to have strong programs in areas related to the symposium topic. Every effort will be made to encourage candidates from underrepresented groups to apply for the registration fee waivers.

Institution.Name: Minerals Metals & Materials Society
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: MINERALS, METALS AND MATERIALS SOCIETY, INC. , THE

POR.DRECONTENT:
The “Deformation, Damage, and Fracture of Light Metals and Alloys” symposium was held at the 2012 Annual Meeting and Exhibition of The Minerals, Metals, and Materials Society (TMS) at the Walt Disney World Swan and Dolphin Resort in Orlando, Florida, 11-15 March 2012, and was partially supported by NSF funding. At this symposium, over 40 talks were delivered over five sessions, spanning three days.

The science surrounding light metals (titanium, aluminum, magnesium) and their alloys is playing an increasingly important role in the reduction of both weight and premature failure of components in a wide variety of applications because of the special properties of these materials. These properties include high strength, light weight, excellent recyclability, and resistance to corrosion. As these materials are used in more applications, both society and the environment will benefit from light-weighting of vehicles, which will contribute to reductions in the use of fossil fuels. These metals and their alloys are widely utilized to manufacture structural components in aircraft, automotive, marine, electronics and construction industries. These structural components often experience forces that lead to deformation, damage, and fracture. Learning to control these effects is essential to seeing these materials utilized to a greater degree.

The symposium topics included studies on: deformation, damage, and fracture mechanisms; the interaction of these effects with other effects such as corrosion; the development of these alloys and the study of their properties; and computer modeling of deformation, damage, and fracture events. Papers from both physical and modeling studies were presented, providing the advantage of a wide breadth of topics and insights.


Last Modified: 02/06/2013
Modified by: George Spanos
